revision.text:
{{Primarysources|date=January 2009}} [[File:Bolsa de Comercio Rosario 1.jpg|thumb|The original Rosario Stock Exchange]] The '''Rosario Board of Trade''' ({{lang-es|'''Bolsa de Comercio de Rosario'''}}, ''BCR'') is a non-profit making association based in [[Rosario]], in the [[provinces of Argentina|Province]] of [[Santa Fe Province|Santa Fe]], [[Argentina]]. Founded on August 18, 1884, it serves as a forum for the conduct of trade negotiations in several markets including grain, oilseed, agricultural products and their by-products, as well as securities and other assets.
== Grain Market == The Physical Grain Market (''{{lang|es|Mercado Físico de Granos}}'') of the BCR is the most important in Argentina in terms of its volume of operations, and provides reference prices for the national and international markets. Most of the country's production of [[cereal]]s and [[Vegetable fats and oils|oilseeds]] is traded within it, especially [[soybean]]. The [[Greater Rosario|region]] around Rosario contains more than 80% of the vegetable oil industry of Argentina and its ports, ([[Port of Rosario|Rosario]] and [[San Lorenzo-Puerto General San Martín Port Complex|San Lorenzo-Puerto San Martín]]), handle more than 90% of the Argentine export of soybean and its derivatives. The Board of Trade additionally operates a complex of laboratories which analyze and provide quality certifications for samples of agricultural products, soil and water.
== Futures Exchange {{anchor|Rosario Futures Exchange}} == The Rosario Futures Exchange (ROFEX, ''{{lang|es|Mercado a Término de Rosario}}'') has traditionally been a [[futures exchange]] for [[commodities]] and, in more recent times, for financial products such as [[exchange rate]] and [[interest rate]] options. Its negotiated volume (especially in [[forward contract]]s over [[United States dollar|dollars]]) makes ROFEX the largest futures market in the country.
== Stock Exchange {{anchor|Rosario Stock Exchange}} == The Rosario Stock Exchange (''{{lang|es|Mercado de Valores de Rosario}}'', abbreviated MerVaRos) is known as ''{{lang|es|Mercado Argentino de Valores}}'', after the merger with the Mendoza Stock Exchange.
== Livestock Market == The Rosario Livestock Market (''{{lang|es|Mercado [[wikt:ganadero|Ganadero]] de Rosario}}'', abbreviated Rosgan) is an important Argentine livestock auction market, notably for [[cattle]].<ref>Official site of [http://www.rosgannet.com.ar/ingles Rosgan] (livestock auction market)</ref>
== History == Operating in a landmark [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] headquarters designed by Raúl Rivero in 1926, the exchange had new offices built during the 1990s. Designed by architect [[Mario Roberto Álvarez]], the new building was completed in 1998.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bcr.com.ar/eng/default.aspx Rosario Board of Trade] * [http://www.mervaros.com.ar/ Mercado Argentino de Valores S.A] {{link language|es}} * [http://www.rofex.com.ar/ ROFEX (Rosario Futures Exchange)] {{link language|es}} * [http://www.argentinaclearing.com.ar Argentina Clearing S.A.] {{link language|es}} * [http://www.rosgan.com.ar/ingles/ ROSGAN]
{{World Federation of Exchanges}}

revision.text:
{{ad|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Rosslyn Data Technologies (aka Rosslyn Analytics) | logo = File:Rosslyn Data Technologies logo.png | type = [[Public Limited Company]] | traded_as = {{aim|RDT}} | genre = | foundation = 2007 | founder = Charles Clark, Hugh Cox | location_city = [[London]] | location_country = [[UK]] | location = | locations = | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = John O’Hara (Chairman)
Roger Bullen (CEO) | industry = [[Business Intelligence]] | products = | services = | market cap = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 50-100 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.rosslynanalytics.com/ www.rosslynanalytics.com] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Rosslyn Data Technologies''' (aka '''Rosslyn Analytics''') ([[London Stock Exchange|LSE]]: [http://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/prices-and-markets/stocks/summary/company-summary.html?fourWayKey=GB00BKX5CP01GBGBXASQ1 RDT]) is a software company providing data extraction, data cleansing and data enrichment technologies to clients through its cloud-based data platform. Its client base includes large enterprises, such as [[Coca-Cola Enterprises]],{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworlduk.com/news/cloud-computing/3303190/coca-cola-bottling-firm-implements-rosslyn-cloud-analytics/|title=Coca-Cola bottling firm implements Rosslyn cloud analytics|author=Leo King|work=Computerworld UK|accessdate=15 January 2015}} Xerox Business Services,{{cite web|url=http://tbrnewscommentary.wordpress.com/2012/04/23/xerox-will-expedite-its-services-led-transformation-by-investing-in-cloud-mobility-analytics-and-vertical-specific-solutions-during-2012/|title=Xerox will expedite its services-led transformation by investing in cloud, mobility, analytics, and vertical-specific solutions during 2012|work=TBR Newsroom|accessdate=15 January 2015}} [[Aberdeen Asset Management]],{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/10509550/Rosslyn-Analytics-raises-2.1m-before-New-Year-IPO.html|title=Rosslyn Analytics raises £2.1m before New Year IPO|date=11 December 2013|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=15 January 2015}} and The [[Weir Group]]. The company is listed on [[Alternative Investment Market|AIM]], a sub-market of the [[London Stock Exchange]], and is headquartered in London with offices in New York City and Chicago, Illinois. ==History== Rosslyn Analytics was founded in 2007 by Charles Clark and Hugh Cox. The company was named after [[Rosslyn Chapel]] in Midlothian, Scotland, which is famous for its mysterious carvings, believed to contain a message or even music that has never been verifiably decoded. In 2009, the company launched its first cloud-based business intelligence product - a self-service spend analytics app for its RAPid data platform. The offering won awards for innovation and excellence, including the Technology Excellence Award for “Best New Product”,{{cite web|url=http://www.bcs.org/content/conWebDoc/35191|title=2009 Technology Excellence Awards winners and medallists - 2009 winners and medallists - 2009 Awards - IT Industry Awards Archive - UK IT Industry Awards - Awards and competitions - Events - BCS - The Chartered Institute for IT|publisher=Bcs.org|accessdate=15 January 2015}} and the ICT Excellence Award for “Best Innovative Service of the Year”.{{cite web|url=http://www.midlandsbusinessnews.co.uk/West-Midlands-ICT-Excellence-Awards-2009-finalists-announced/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20150118133621/http://www.midlandsbusinessnews.co.uk/West-Midlands-ICT-Excellence-Awards-2009-finalists-announced/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=18 January 2015|title=Midlands Business News West Midlands ICT Excellence Awards 2009 finalists announced - Midlands Business News|work=Midlands Business News|accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{Unreliable source?|reason=Invites user submissions. Contact us notes "Press releases and news items submitted are reviewed as to their news value and suitability for our audience", but PR is not labeled and source is not disclosed.|date=March 2016}} In April 2011, as a public service to help the UK Government reduce the deficit by getting better control of its purchasing, Rosslyn Analytics offered to provide free spend analytics to the government in just 30 days. The government refused the offer.{{cite web|url=http://spendmatters.com/uk/rosslyn-analytics-govenrment/|title=Rosslyn Analytics p*** off the Government with procurement data analysis offer|work=Spend Matters|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In January 2012, Rosslyn Analytics entered the United States establishing offices in New York City and Denver, Colorado. Rosslyn Analytics was the first technology company to bring QlikView into the cloud in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://investor.qlikview.com/common/mobile/iphone/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=666260&CompanyID=ABEA-4QVVLE&mobileid=|title=QLIK - NASDAQ|publisher=Investor.qlikview.com|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In 2013, Rosslyn Analytics was featured in Gartner’s Magic Quadrant for Strategic Sourcing Application Suites.{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/208839487/Gartner-MQ-2013-Sourcing-Suites|title=Gartner MQ 2013 - Sourcing Suites|publisher=Scribd.com|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In February 2014, the company filed its first patent with the UK Intellectual Property Office{{cite web|url=http://www.ipo.gov.uk/p-pj?lastResult=50&perPage=10&startYear=2014&startMonth=April&startDay=02th+-+6515&endYear=2014&endMonth=April&endDay=02th+-+6515&filter=&sort=Publication+Date&status=undefined|title=IPO : Searchable Patents Journal|publisher=Ipo.gov.uk|accessdate=15 January 2015}} on machine-learning. In April, Rosslyn Analytics went public on AIM under the name of Rosslyn Data Technologies Group plc.{{cite web|url=http://www.iii.co.uk/research/LSE:RDT/news/item/1065958/admission-aim-and-first-day-dealings|title=ROSSLYN DATA Share News - RDT Stock News - Interactive Investor|work=Interactive Investor|accessdate=15 January 2015}}In May, Rosslyn Analytics joined the UK government’s G-Cloud 5 Framework for Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) providers.{{cite web|url=http://www.westerndailypress.co.uk/Rosslyn-Analytics-announce-self-service-spend/story-21147074-detail/story.html|title=Rosslyn Analytics announce self-service spend analytics solution is now free for councils|work=Western Daily Press|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In May 2015, Pricewaterhouse Coopers (PwC) partnered with Rosslyn Analytics to offer cloud-based big data services to clients.{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesscloudnews.com/2015/05/05/pwc-rosslyn-partner-on-cloudy-big-data/|title=PwC, Rosslyn partner on cloudy big data {{!}} Business Cloud News|website=www.businesscloudnews.com|access-date=2018-06-12}} == Recognition == In January 2011, JMP Securities recognized Rosslyn Analytics as one of its “Hot 100” software companies to watch.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswings.co.uk/articles/Six-tech-companies-to-look-out-for|title=Six tech companies to look out for|publisher=Businesswings.co.uk|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In March 2013, Bessemer named Rosslyn Analytics as one of the top Business Intelligence / Analytics cloud companies.{{cite web|url=http://www.bvp.com/cloud|title=Cloud Computing|publisher=Bvp.com|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In December 2015, Rosslyn Analytics was named a strong performer in the Forrester Research report, “The Forrester Wave™: Cloud Business Intelligence Platforms, Q4 2015.”{{cite web|url=https://www.forrester.com/The+Forrester+Wave+Cloud+Business+Intelligence+Platforms+Q4+2015/fulltext/-/E-RES113305|title=The Forrester Wave™: Cloud Business Intelligence Platforms, Q4 2015|work=Forrester Research|accessdate=7 January 2016}} In May 2016, Rosslyn Analytics recognized as finalist for the 2016 Microsoft Data Platform Partner of the Year award https://news.microsoft.com/2016/05/31/microsoft-announces-2016-partner-of-the-year-winners-and-finalists/#k2eZjv1T1PllGIUo.97 In March 2017, Rosslyn Data Technologies was shortlisted for analytics product of the year in the UK Cloud Awards. http://ukcloudawards.co.uk/2017-shortlist == Products == The company’s flagship product is its cloud-based data platform called RAPid. RAPid provides self-service data integration, cleansing, enrichment, analysis and visualization capabilities via a single platform. Business users access the benefits of the platform via automated and manual self-service tools.{{cn|date=February 2018}} The RAPid platform comes with a number of pre-built analytical apps sold as modular [[solution]]s such as spend analytics, people analytics, forensics analytics, expense analytics and supplier performance management. ==Founders== Rosslyn Analytics was founded by Charles Clark and Hugh Cox, two former British Army officers. Charles has been recognized for his leadership by Supply & Demand Chain Executive, having been identified as a “Pro to Know” from 2010 to 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.sdcexec.com/article/10269268/2010-pros-to-know|title=2010 Pros to Know|work=Supply & Demand Chain Executive|accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sdcexec.com/article/10243158/2011-pros-to-know|title=2011 Pros to Know|work=Supply & Demand Chain Executive|accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sdcexec.com/article/10885560/supply-chain-pros-to-know|title=Supply Chain Pros to Know - Supply & Demand Chain Executive|work=Supply & Demand Chain Executive|accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sdcexec.com/news/10879380/supply-demand-chain-executive-announces-2013-pros-to-know-award-winners|title=Supply & Demand Chain Executive Announces 2013 "Pros to Know" Award Winners|work=Supply & Demand Chain Executive|accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sdcexec.com/article/11321647/meet-ryan-verbecken-our-pro-of-the-year-as-well-as-all-the-other-men-and-women-making-a-difference-in-supply-chain|title=Meet Ryan Verbecken, our Pro of the Year, as well as all the other men and women making a difference in supply chain|work=Supply & Demand Chain Executive|accessdate=15 January 2015}} Hugh Cox is the company’s Chief Data Officer. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:British companies established in 2007]] [[Category:Business intelligence companies]] [[Category:Business software companies]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Alternative Investment Market]] [[Category:Software companies based in London]] [[Category:Technology companies established in 2007]]

revision.comment: /* Growing scope of Rural Management in India */ Added links
revision.text:
'''<big>Rural management</big>''' is the study of planning, organising, directing, and controlling of [[rural area]], [[Cooperative|co-operatives]], [[agribusiness]] and allied fields. It merges the knowledge of [[Management|management studies]] and applying it in the rural context. Most of the courses are designed in such a way that the concepts taught in the class is applied in the real life through training in the rural areas through [[Case study|case-studies]] and interaction with the rural people
== Rural Management Institutes in India ==
There are many academic institutions within India offering courses on Rural Management. Notable among them are Institute of Rural Management, Anand (www.irma.ac.in), KIIT School of Rural Management (KSRM), Bhubaneswar (ksrm.ac.in) and Xavier University, Bhubaneswar (ximb.ac.in). They offer either two years' Post Graduate Diploma in Rural Management or Two Years' Masters in Business Administration (MBA-Rural Management).
Rural Management graduates work in the areas like sustainable rural livelihoods, agri-business management, cooperatives, climate change, micro-finance, [[corporate social responsibility]], [[Natural resource management|natural resources managemen]]<nowiki/>t, rural marketing, commodity trading and marketing and [[social entrepreneurship]].
Apart from the classroom based courses, IRMA and KSRM provide opportunities to their rural management students to undergo three field segments (internships) of 10–11 weeks duration. In other words, the curriculum is designed to make it contextual to develop rural areas through experiential learning, live projects.
* Institute of Rural Management, Anand, Gujarat, India - www.irma.ac.in * [http://www.ksrm.ac.in/ KIIT School of Rural Management] (MBA-Rural Management)- KIIT University, Bhubaneswar, Odisha, India * Xavier School of Rural Management, Xavier University, Bhubaneswar, Odisha, India www.xsrm.edu.in
== Growing scope of Rural Management in India == India has close to 4,000 management schools that produce over 300,000 graduates every year. But the country has few niche management schools focusing on the rural sector. Rural management schools produce less than 1,000 rural managers. The small number is surprising considering the importance of the rural sector, or Bharat, in India's economy.
According to a study by global consulting firm Accenture, the rural economy accounts for 50 per cent of the country's gross domestic product. It also makes up 70 per cent of the country's population and 50 per cent of the work force. About 75 percent of new factories built in the past decade have come up in rural India, which accounts for 75 per cent of all new manufacturing jobs. Since 2000, per capita GDP has grown at 6.2 per cent a year in rural India compared with 4.2 per cent in urban areas. And in terms of spending, Bharat has trumped India by a mile. Between 2009 and 2012, Indians in the countryside spent $69 billion compared with $55 billion in big towns and cities.
Harish Manwani, chairman of Hindustan Unilever Ltd, says rural India is a powerhouse with the potential to add $1.8 trillion, or the equivalent of the current GDP, to the country's economy. But this potential can be realised only if Bharat and India merge.
Mainstream management schools have not ventured into rural management for many reasons. The rural management courses are very niche and they call for students with a different set of attitudes. The teaching approach is also different. Most mainstream schools may not be prepared to handle such subjects," says Professor Abraham Koshy, professor of marketing at the Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad. Experts say there is room for more rural management schools. For a country of India's size and the number of problems we face, there is a need for lot more such institutions. There is a need to create a lot of rural managers who are potential agents of change.
Rural Management is one such specialisation which gives you the chance to contribute towards uplifting and betterment of those sections of the society, where the light of development is yet to reach. The purpose of the rural managers is to promote sustainable, eco-friendly and equitable socioeconomic development of rural area through professional management of their institutions and organisations. Previously, only a few people opted for this challenging course but nowadays, a lot of students are opting for this course of rural management as they want to learn and showcase their skills to ensure that the performance in the rural sector is enhanced..
== Unique areas of Rural Management in terms of course and career == The MBA (Rural Management) programme is unique in the sense that in addition to traditional management courses such as Project Management, Accounting, Quantitative Techniques, Managerial Analysis and Communication, Finance, Marketing Management, many specialised courses focusing on management of rural sector are offered.
Agribusiness Management, Rural Production and Livelihoods, Rural Finance and Commercial Banking, Natural Resources Management and Climate Change, Rural Marketing, CSR Management, Micro Finance, ICTs for Development, Innovation in Rural Development and Enterprises, Policy and Programme Interventions in Rural Development are some of the courses especially focusing on the rural sector.
Anyone who completes MBA (Rural Management) has the advantage of having career opportunities in any general management area. In addition to that, Rural Management graduates alone are preferred in specific areas mentioned above.
== External links ==
* MS Sriram: [http://www.dhan.org/tda/pdf/ms_sriram.pdf Rural Management Education in India- A Retrospect] IIM- Ahmedabad-2007 *Arun Kumar. [http://vitm.edu.in/_notes/IIm-lucknow.pdf Rural Management Education in India- A Restrospect]. IIM-Lucknow- 2014 *KIIT School of Rural Management (KSRM), Bhubaneswar which came into existence with the laying of the foundation stone by the father of the White Revolution, Late Dr. [[Verghese Kurien]] & [https://achyutasamanta.com/ Dr. Achyuta Samanta] offering MBA (Rural Management) course: http://www.ksrm.ac.in/ *[http://www.ksrm.ac.in/95th-birth-anniversary-of-the-legendary-dr-verghese-kurien/ KSRM Celebrating the 95th Birth Anniversary of the Legendary Dr. Verghese Kurien] *[http://niti.gov.in/writereaddata/files/document_publication/Rural_Economy_DP_final.pdf Changing Structure of Rural Economy of India -Implications for Employment and Growth- NITI Aayog] *[http://www.pondiuni.edu.in/storage/dde/downloads/markiv_rm.pdf Rural Marketing is Real Marketing] *[http://journals.sagepub.com/home/irm# International Journal of Rural Management- international journal that focuses exclusively on rural management] *[http://yojana.gov.in/Final%20Kuru%20December%202015.pdf Social Change in Rural India] *[https://rural.nic.in/ Ministry of Rural Development, Government of India]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
'''Sven Trygve Falck''' (born 9 March 1943) is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] engineer, businessperson and politician for the [[Conservative Party (Norway)|Conservative Party]].
He was born in [[Tønsberg]] as a son of bookseller Trygve Falck (1905-1974) and housewife Inger Erikson (1909-1995). He finished his secondary education in 1962 and took the [[Sivilingeniør|siv.ing.]] degree in [[chemical engineering]] at the [[Norwegian Institute of Technology]] in 1967. While studying he edited ''[[Under Dusken]]'' in 1964.<ref name=bio>{{stortingetbio|SVFA}}</ref>
His first engineering job was at [[Dow Chemical Co.]] in Texas from 1967 to 1970. After a year at Dow Chemical Co. in Germany, he was hired in [[Norsk Hydro]] in 1971. He was an engineer for Norsk Hydro at [[Rafnes]] from 1975, then chief engineer for Norsk Hydro in [[Porsgrunn]] from 1976 to 1981.<ref name=bio/>
He was a member of Porsgrunn city council from 1977 to 1979, then the executive committee of [[Telemark]] [[county council (Norway)|county council]] while also serving as deputy chair of the county school board. He was also elected to the [[Parliament of Norway]] from Telemark in [[Norwegian parliamentary election, 1981|1981]], and served through one term as a member of the [[Standing Committee on Energy and the Environment|Standing Committee on Energy and Industry]].<ref name=bio/>
After leaving Parliament he was a consultant and business director. He was a board member of Norsk Jern Holding from 1990 to 1993, corporate council member of [[Norsk Jernverk]] from 1987 to 1989 and supervisory council member of [[Manufacturers Hanover|Manufacturers Hanover Norge]] from 1986 to 1990 and [[Den Norske Industribank]] from 1990 to 1993 (deputy from 1986 to 1990).<ref name=bio/>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Chinese name|[[Chen (surname)|Tan (Chen)]]}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Tan Chin Tuan |office = Chairman of the [[Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation]] |native_name = {{nobold|陈振传}} |native_name_lang = zh-sg |image = Tan Chin Tuan Statue.jpeg |caption = A bust of Tan Chin Tuan in front of the lecture theatre named after him at [[Nanyang Technological University]] |predecessor = |successor = |birth_date = {{birth date|1908|11|21|df=yes}} |birth_place = |death_date = {{death date and age|2005|11|13|1908|11|21|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Singapore]] |spouse = [[Helene Tan|Puan Sri Helene Tan]] |relations = [[Tony Tan]] {{small|(nephew)}} |children = Tan Keng Siong {{small|(son)}}
Tan Kheng Lian {{small|(daughter)}}
Tan Kheng Choo {{small|(daughter)}} |alma_mater = [[Anglo-Chinese School]] |term_start = 1966 |term_end = 1983 }} (Dr) '''Tan Chin Tuan''' ({{zh|s=陈振传|t=陳振傳|p=Chén Zhèn Chuán}}; 21 November 1908 – 13 November 2005) was a [[Peranakan]] banker and philanthropist who is often credited with helping to build up [[Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation]] (OCBC). == Biography == === Early life === Born in 1908, he was the son of prominent Hokkien businessman, Tan Cheng Siong, a General Manager of Oversea-Chinese Bank Ltd. Tan Chin Tuan grew up under the harsh conditions of the [[Great Depression|Great Depression (1930)]], having lost his father during his schooling years. Educated at [[Anglo-Chinese School]], he was compelled to leave school at the age of seventeen to begin work at the Chinese Commercial Bank (which merged with Ho Hong Bank that same year to form OCBC).{{cite web|title=Tan Chin Tuan|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_155_2004-12-27.html|website=Singapore Infopedia|publisher=National Library Board Singapore|accessdate=10 October 2015}} === Career === Tan served as the managing director of OCBC from 1942 to 1972 and as chairman from 1966 to 1983. Upon his retirement, he was made honorary life president of the bank, the only person ever thus honoured. Tan established his reputation as a sharp corporate banker with a keen eye for spotting opportunities to create value for the bank and its shareholders. His ideas and thinking were instrumental in the building of OCBC bank. Between the mid-1950s to the mid-1970s, he was chairman of ten blue-chip companies. Upon his retirement of these companies, Tan was made their Honorary Life President.{{cite web|title=Tan Chin Tuan's Biography|url=http://www.geni.com/people/TAN-Chin-Tuan-%E9%99%88%E6%8C%AF%E4%BC%A0/6000000025343675571|website=Gini|accessdate=10 October 2015}} === Philanthropist === Tan Chin Tuan was a strong advocate of lifelong learning. In 1984, he donated £350,000 to the [[Needham Research Institute]] (NRI) in Cambridge, United Kingdom and the library block at NRI is named after him. NRI is currently one of the top three centres for learning Chinese science and technology in the world.{{cite web|title=Needham Legacy and China’s Genius|url=http://lampinfoo.com/2008/09/15/needham-legacy-and-chinas-genius/|website=Lam Pin Foo: My Reflections on Life|accessdate=10 October 2015}} In 1997, he committed S$2.5 million towards the [[Nanyang Technological University]]'s exchange programme in engineering. Named the Tan Chin Tuan Exchange Fellowship, it funds research collaborations between NTU and overseas institutes. Tan established the Tan Chin Tuan Foundation (TCTF) on 10 April 1976 to share with society the rewards of his highly illustrious career. He rendered assistance to the deserving and provided services that helped uplift the less fortunate. Today, the contributions of TCTF reflect the founder’s philosophy of how money should be channelled for social good. The foundation strives to support causes and projects that are viable, sustainable and well-managed with definable social outcomes.{{cite web|title=About the Tan Chin Tuan Foundation|url=http://tanfoundation.com.sg/the-foundation/about-the-foundation/|website=Tan Chin Tuan|accessdate=10 October 2015}} Today, TCTF continues his commitment towards advancing educational causes through professorships, scholarships and bursaries, and establishing strategic programmes in institutions of higher learning. == Awards == * Tan was awarded the prestigious Commander of the [[Most Excellent Order of the British Empire]] for his contributions during his service in the Legislative Council in 1951 * His title of Tan Sri was conferred to him by Malaysia's [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong|Yang Di Pertuan Agong Sultan Tuanku Ismail Nasiruddin Shah]] (Supreme Head of State) of Malaysia on 31 August 1969. * Tan was conferred an honorary Doctor of Laws by the late Singapore President Wee Kim Wee, who was the Chancellor of the National University of Singapore at its Convocation on 3 September 1991. * In 1992, [[Curtin University|Curtin University of Technology, Australia]] honoured Tan with an honorary doctorate in appreciation of his long personal and professional ties with Australia. ==Honour== ===Foreign honour=== * {{flagu|Malaysia}} : Honorary Commander of the [[Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia#Commander|Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia]] (P.S.M.) (1969){{cite web |url=http://www.istiadat.gov.my/index.php/component/semakanlantikanskp/|title=Semakan Penerima Darjah Kebesaran, Bintang dan Pingat}} == References == {{Reflist|20em}} {{Use British English|date=October 2015}} {{use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1908 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:Singaporean businesspeople]] [[Category:Singaporean people of Peranakan descent]] [[Category:Honorary Commanders of the Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Teresa de Dios Unanue |other_names = de Dios Unanue, Teresa; de Dios Unanue, Teresa, de Dios, Unanue |image = Teresa_de_Dios_Unanue_Foto.jpg |image_size = 120 px |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Camagüey]], [[Cuba]] |residence = Puerto Rico |nationality = Puerto Rican {{flag|Puerto Rico}} |known_for = |education = Ph.D. in Human Behavior |alma_mater = [[University of Puerto Rico]] |employer = |occupation = |home_town = |title = President at [[Atlantic University College]] |salary = |networth = |predecessor = |successor = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |children = |relations = |signature = |website = [http://www.atlanticu.edu atlanticu.edu] |footnotes = }} Dr. '''Teresa de Dios Unanue''' is an educator, civic leader, the author of several essays published in [[Puerto Rico]] and the [[United States]], the co-author of the book Educación Personalizada (Personalized Education),[http://www.worldcat.org/title/educacion-personalizada/oclc/20175194&referer=brief_results the book Educación Personalizada (Personalized Education)] and the co-founder and Executive President of [[Atlantic University College]], a university institution specializing in digital arts in Puerto Rico and [[Caribbean]]. ==Early years== Dr. Teresa de Dios Unanue was born in [[Camagüey]], [[Cuba]]. She was later exiled and settled in [[Puerto Rico]], where she graduated with distinction from the [[University of Puerto Rico]] in the fields of [[literature]], [[Management|administration]] and educational supervision. She also has a [[doctoral degree]] in Human Behavior. Years later, after graduating from the university, she began to work as Director of Innovation and Curriculum at the American Military Academy. From there, she proceeded to found the company which she now directs. She is the sister of the late journalist [[Manuel de Dios Unanue]] whose murder in 1992 made international headlines. ==Co-founder of Atlantic University College== Dr. Teresa de Dios Unanue has dedicated her life to the development of Puerto Rican children and youths. In 1983, Dr. de Dios began her work developing Atlantic University College,[http://www.atlanticu.edu Atlantic University College] the only university institution in [[Guaynabo, Puerto Rico|Guaynabo]], [[Puerto Rico]]. She is a co-founder of the College, and currently serves as its President. This university institution has been credited with strengthening the city's economy. Similarly, [[Atlantic University College]] is considered to be a pioneer in digital arts on the island. Another great success of Dr. de Dios was her establishment of the historic first [[bachelor's degree]] in [[graphic arts]], and the incorporation into the College's curriculum, in 2001, of the first [[master's degree]] in [[graphic arts]] in [[Puerto Rico]] and the [[Caribbean]] which specializes in digital graphic design. Also, in 2014, the Master of Science in Interactive Technologies Programming == Awards and accomplishments == Dr. de Dios's efforts, and her educational and administrative work, have transcended boundaries. Under her presidency, and together with the Executive Vice-President Heri Martínez de Dios, she has received recognition such as the award and rank of Honorary Institution with Distinction, awarded by the [[Accrediting Council for Independent Colleges and Schools]] (ACICS),[http://www.acics.org/ “Accrediting Council for Independent Colleges and Schools”, ACICS] and the prestigious [[Emmy Award]] in 2007[http://www.businessweek.com/adsections/2009/pdf/11.16.09_islandeconomies.pdf Premio Emmy 2007] in the category of Technical Achievement,[http://www.businessweek.com/adsections/2009/pdf/11.16.09_islandeconomies.pdf Awarded an Emmy award for Technical Achievement in 2007] an Emmy ® Award in 2012[http://www.elnuevodia.com/destacalaanimacionlocalconfloxyyjulio-1367933.html Awarded an Emmy ® award in 2012.] and nominated for three Emmy ® awards in 2011.[http://www.primerahora.com/entretenimiento/tv/nota/puertoricoconvariasnominacionesenlospremiosemmy-568115 Nominated for three Emmy ® awards in 2011.] It is worth noting that [http://www.atlanticu.edu Atlantic University College], under the leadership of Dr. de Dios, is the only institution in [[Puerto Rico]] and the [[Caribbean]] which has received this award. [[Image:Doctora Guaynabena Distinguida.jpg|thumbnail|left|200px|Teresa de Dios Unanue received the Distinguished Guaynabo Resident award from the city of Guaynabo, Puerto Rico]] She also received the Kappan of the Year award for her voluntary work with disadvantaged youths in the Peruvian Republic School in the Luis Llorens Torres public housing project, as well as the Paloma de la Paz (Dove of Peace), Outstanding Businesswoman, and Distinguished Guaynabo Resident prizes,[https://web.archive.org/web/20080404203255/http://www.guaynabocity.gov.pr/Guaynabo/Mayor+Office/News/Noche+Guaynabena.htm Teresa de Dios Unanue received the Distinguished Guaynabo Resident award from the city of Guaynabo] all awarded by the city of Guaynabo in recognition of her contribution to the development of [[culture]] and the [[arts]] in the city, and the Hero of Our Times prize awarded by Doral Financial Corporation[[Doral Financial Corporation]] for her work in the interest of the well-being of the Puerto Rican people. She has also been recognized by the newspaper Caribbean Business[[Caribbean Business]] as one of the island's leading women in its reports 'Women in Leadership', 'Women Who Rule 2008' and 'Women Who Lead 2010', and has also been recognized by the Puerto Rican UNESCO organization[[UNESCO|Unesco]] for her services and work, and her contributions to culture.
In addition to this, on September 27, 2010, the President of the Senate of Puerto Rico, [[Thomas Rivera Schatz]], together with former senate president [[Charlie Rodríguez|Cherlie Rodríguez]], dedicated a congratulatory motion to Dr. Teresa de Dios Unanue,[http://www.senadopr.us/Comunicados_de_Prensa/Comunicado_de_Prensa_Teresa_de_Dios_Unanue.pdf Congratulatory Motion from the Senate of Puerto Rico to Dr. Teresa de Dios Unanue]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} in which her personal, academic and professional record was highlighted, as well as her achievements and contributions to [[higher education]] in [[Puerto Rico]]. In addition to her contributions as an educator, Dr. de Dios is a civic leader, essayist, and the co-author of the book [http://www.worldcat.org/title/educacion-personalizada/oclc/20175194&referer=brief_results Educación Personalizada (Personalized Education)]. [[Image:Reconocimiento a Doctora de Dios.jpg|thumbnail|right|200px|Teresa de Dios Unanue with her husband Professor Heriberto Martinez receive the recognition from the President of the Senate]] == Philanthropy and community work == Dr. de Dios currently dedicates a large proportion of her time to work carried out in order to benefit [[culture]] and young people. She is a member of the board of directors of the Centre of Fine Arts in [[Guaynabo, Puerto Rico]], and a volunteer on the city's Community Evaluation Committee. From [[Atlantic University College]], she endorses and assists causes and events which support educational, artistic and cultural development in [[Puerto Rico]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140522142742/http://www.atlanticu.edu/presidenta.php Atlantic University College Official Website] ==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|Biography}} *[[List of Puerto Ricans]] {{clear}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dios Unanue, Teresa De}} [[Category:Puerto Rican educators]] [[Category:Puerto Rican women writers]] [[Category:University of Puerto Rico alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Puerto Rican businesspeople]] [[Category:Cuban emigrants to Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Puerto Rican women in business]] [[Category:Puerto Rican non-fiction writers]] [[Category:21st-century Puerto Rican educators]] [[Category:21st-century Puerto Rican writers]] [[Category:21st-century Puerto Rican women writers]] [[Category:American women non-fiction writers]]

revision.text:
{{Company|name=TESTEX AG|logo=Logo TESTEX.png|founded={{Start date and age|1846|09|22}} in [[Zurich]], Switzerland|industry=Textile testing, certification|hq_location_city=Zurich, Switzerland|key_people=[[Serge Rolle]] ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]])|num_employees=>200|website={{URL|http://www.testex.com/}}|logo_size=100px|logo_padding=20px}}
'''Testex''', stylized as '''TESTEX''', is a globally operating, independent Swiss testing and [[certification]] organisation that focuses on [[textile]] testing. The Testex corporate group is headquartered in [[Zürich|Zurich]] and consists of the Testex AG, ÖTI GmbH ([[Austria]]), PT Testex ([[Indonesia]]), Swiss Textile-Testing Ltd. Hong Kong, and Testex Testing Co. Ltd. Beijing. Testex AG emerged from the “Seidentrocknungsanstalt Zurich” founded in 1846, and operates more than 20 branches<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.testex.com/en/leistungen/wer-wir-sind/|title=TESTEX - Who we are|website=www.testex.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> worldwide. Testex is the official representative of the [[Oeko-tex standard|Oeko-Tex]] Association in [[Australia]], [[Canada]], the [[China|P.R. China]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]], [[New Zealand]], the [[Philippines]], [[Switzerland]], [[South Korea]] and [[Taiwan]].
== Operations ==
=== Analytical Testing === The analytical [[laboratory]] at Testex is [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] 17025 certified<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sas.admin.ch/sas/en/home/akkreditiertestellen/akkrstellensuchesas.exturl.html/aHR0cHM6Ly9zYXNkYi5jbGllbnRzLmxpaXAuY2gvc2VhcmNoLm/h0bWw=.html?csrfmiddlewaretoken=O3u1qff2wX6unur97BqMXYcmmaOL8Suk5tqR3ru8vdCKCFHgOAuwfc3JSeRP6gnH&lang=en&search_term=Testex&accreditation_type=&submit=Start+search|title=Search Accredited Bodies SAS|last=SAS|first=Swiss Accreditation Service|website=www.sas.admin.ch|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> and conducts a variety of analytical tests designed to detect pollutants, residues, and trace elements in textiles. Testing and auditing are also conducted in accordance with the guidelines specified by the Oeko-Tex Association. These include [[Oeko-tex standard|Standard 100 by Oeko-Tex]], Step, Made in green, Eco passport, Allergy Standards<ref>[https://www.allergystandards.com "Allergy Standards"]. allergystandards.com Allergy Standards Limited.</ref> and the Leather standard. The product portfolio is continually adapted according to the current market needs.
=== Physical and Chemical Textile Testing === Testex conducts physical and chemical tests on [[Fiber|fibers]], [[Yarn|yarns]]/ strings, [[Woven fabric|woven fabrics]], [[Knitted fabric|knitted fabrics]], [[Nonwoven fabric|nonwoven fabrics]], and finished products. The services also include physiological tests on textile fabrics and ready-made [[Textile|textiles]], flooring tests and the testing of personal protective equipment (PPE) in accordance with ISO 17065, <ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/growth/tools-databases/nando/index.cfm?fuseaction=notification.html&ntf_id=263456&version_no=3|title=EUROPA - European Commission - Growth - Regulatory policy - NANDO|website=ec.europa.eu|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> which involves various flaming tests.
== History ==
=== The Silk Industry in Zurich === As early as 1237, raw silk was documented to be brought to Zurich from [[Como]] via [[Walenstadt]]. At that time, shipments were transported in primitive vehicles on poorly paved roads, narrow bridle paths, and dangerously labile, unstable footbridges<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Hundert Jahre Seidentrocknungs-Anstalt Zürich, 1846–1946.|last=Jenny|first=Hans|publisher=Orell Füssli AG|year=1946|isbn=|location=Zurich|pages=4|language=German}}</ref>. Back then, transporting silk was much more laborious and hazardous than it is today. To reach [[Chur]] and adjacently Walenstadt, traders were forced to pass the [[Septimer Pass]] and the old imperial road. From there, the goods were transported to Zurich by boat. Upon arrival, the silk was unloaded near the [[Wasserkirche|Helmhaus]] Bridge and sold in a store near the [[Fraumünster]].<ref name=":1" />
=== Silk Drying === [[File:Trocknungsöfen.jpg|thumb|The drying ovens of the "Seidentrocknungsanstalt Zürich" around 1918]] In order to determine the curb weight of [[silk]], it must be completely dry. However, this process is heavily influenced by the atmospheric humidity, since the material absorbs moisture from the air and thereby increases in weight<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hundert Jahre Seidentrocknungs-Anstalt Zürich, 1846–1946.|last=Jenny|first=Hans|publisher=Orell Füssli AG|year=1946|isbn=|location=Zurich|pages=19|language=German}}</ref> This property of raw silk makes it difficult to accurately determine its weight, which created the need for independent “weighing institutes”. These institutes were established to dry all traders’ silk according to a standardized method and thereby ensure a fair silk trade. Per definition, a silk conditioning institute is “a neutral authority whose test results are recognized as binding by both contractual parties."<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Hundert Jahre Seidentrocknungs-Anstalt Zürich, 1846–1946.|last=Jenny|first=Hans|publisher=Orell Füssli AG|year=1946|isbn=|location=Zurich|pages=24|language=German}}</ref>
The first silk conditioning institute opened on April 8, 1724 in [[Turin]].<ref name=":2" /> It would remain the only institution of its kind until Jean-Louis Rast-Maupas opened a similar institution with improved procedures in [[Lyon]] in 1779. During the [[French Revolution]], Rast-Maupas's “Condition” was closed for nearly two years. During this time, three similar institutes opened in Lyon, setting off a fierce competition. In 1805, [[Napoleon]] granted the Lyon [[Chamber of commerce|Chamber of Commerce]] the exclusive right to dry silk, resulting in the establishment of a state institution in 1814.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hundert Jahre Seidentrocknungs-Anstalt Zürich, 1846–1946.|last=Jenny|first=Hans|publisher=Orell Füssli AG|year=1946|isbn=|location=Zurich|pages=22|language=German}}</ref> Following the establishment of institutions in Turin, Lyon, and [[Milan]], others quickly followed in [[Elberfeld]], [[Krefeld]], [[Saint-Étienne]], [[Vienna]], [[Zürich|Zurich]], and, finally, in [[New York City|New York]], [[Yokohama]], [[Kobe]], [[Shanghai]], and [[Guangzhou]].<ref name=":2" />
=== Founding === The silk industry experienced a considerable boom around 1846. It became obvious that it would be disadvantageous to remain dependent on foreign silk conditioning institutions, a “provisional committee” decided to establish a silk drying institute in Zurich. On September 22nd, 1846, the constitutive assembly approved the statutes. Nearly 50 silk experts gathered in the “[[Zunfthaus zur Zimmerleuten|Zunfthaus zur Zimmerläuten]]” to elect a [[board of directors]] for the newly founded institute. Colonel Heinrich von Muralt-Stockar was elected Chairman of the Board,<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hundert Jahre Seidentrocknungs-Anstalt Zürich, 1846–1946.|last=Jenny|first=Hans|publisher=Orell Füssli|year=1946|isbn=|location=Zurich|pages=28|language=German}}</ref> and Lord Schwarzenbach-Imhof was appointed as director. Three days later the board met for the first time, and operations began on June 1st, 1847. At that time, they did not yet have any practical experience in silk drying.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hundert Jahre Seidentrocknungs-Anstalt Zürich, 1846–1946.|last=Jenny|first=Hans|publisher=Orell Füssli AG|year=1946|isbn=|location=Zurich|pages=29}}</ref>
Three individuals were primarily responsible for the founding of the Silk Drying Institute in Zurich. They became aware of silk drying while travelling abroad and wanted to establish the practice in Switzerland in order to make the local silk trade less dependent on foreign entities. All three were politically active and well-known throughout the city.
Colonel Heinrich von Muralt-Stockar served as Chairman of the Board for 14 consecutive years, he was the son of Hans Conrad von Muralt, the former mayor of Zurich. At the age of 27, he took over his father’s silk business “Heinrich de Daniel Muralt” and served as president of Zurich’s “Baukollegium”, and the “Dampfschifffahrtsgesellschaft”.
Cavalry Captain Conrad Bürkli, a senior commander of the fire brigade, was a close friend of von Muralt's. He had been the proprietor of the Johann Georg Bürkli silk trading company since 1811, as well as a member of the city council.
Johann Heinrich (Henry) Bodmer-Pestalozzi was a member of the Bodmer zur Arch family and owner of the family’s eponymous silk production company. The company was among the first in Switzerland to produce silk [[gauze]].
=== Facilities === [[File:Neubau Gotthardstrasse.jpg|thumb|The newly constructed headquarters in April 1932 at the Gotthardstrasse 61, Zürich]] Between 1846 and 1863, the Silk Drying Institute resided in the “Äusseren Tiefenhof”, where the [[headquarters]] of the [[Zurich Cantonal Bank]] are located at present. The facility, located in the center of Zurich, covered roughly 5,525 square feet.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hundert Jahre Seidentrocknungs-Anstalt Zürich, 1846–1946.|last=Jenny|first=Hans|publisher=Orell Füssli AG|year=1946|isbn=|location=Zurich|pages=31|language=German}}</ref> On October 1st, 1849, a new branch was opened in [[Basel]], which would later detach itself organizationally and financially from its parent company in 1872.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hundert Jahre Seidentrocknungs-Anstalt Zürich, 1846–1946.|last=Jenny|first=Hans|publisher=Orell Füssli AG|year=1946|isbn=|location=Zurich|pages=33|language=German}}</ref> Due to the company’s rapid growth and an acute need for additional space, a new facility was acquired in 1861: the “weissen Bären,” located on the corner of Bärengasse and Talstrasse. The company officially moved to the new facility in 1863, after two years of renovations and furnishing. The facility remained in use until 1932, when it was replaced by the company’s present-day headquarters in [[Enge (Zürich)|Zurich’s Enge]] district, which officially opened on April 14th, 1932. Although an expansion of the company’s operational space had been in discussion since as early as 1889, the implementation was delayed, due to [[World War I]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Hundert Jahre Seidentrocknungs-Anstalt Zürich, 1846–1946.|last=Jenny|first=Hans|publisher=Orell Füssli AG|year=1946|isbn=|location=Zurich|pages=77|language=German}}</ref>
=== The Zurich Silk Industry in Its Prime === In the second half of the [[19th century]], free trade policies and technological advances such as the [[telephone]] and the [[Telegraphy|telegraph,]] introduced a period of prosperity for the silk trade. The [[Gotthard railway|Gotthard railway connection]], completed in 1882, and the completion of the [[Suez Canal]] in 1869 made international trade significantly easier. On account of its constant improvements to the silk drying procedure and improved logistics and storage, Zurich became the center of the international silk trade.
=== The War and Post-War Eras === Zurich retained this status during World War I despite the difficult conditions, which caused interruptions and declines in sales. Many banks and other businesses closed following the outbreak of war. This resulted in a shortage of liquid funds, which soon impacted the silk trade. The home countries of the institutions in Milan, Turin, Lyon, Krefeld, and later [[Tokyo]] and New York, had entered the war. This favored the silk industry in Zurich tremendously, hence it achieved record sales between 1915 and 1917.<ref name=":3" />
=== World War II === While the transition from a peacetime economy to a wartime economy posed fewer issues in [[World War II]] than it did in World War I, the war years were even tougher for the silk trade. As a national economy, Switzerland was largely cut off from foreign markets. While the silk trade was exempt from rationing measures, it was subordinated to the Swiss Textile Syndicate along with all other branches of the textile industry. The export guarantee issued by the [[Swiss Federal Council]] eased the situation for exports only.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hundert Jahre Seidentrocknungs-Anstalt Zürich, 1846–1946.|last=Jenny|first=Hans|publisher=Orell Füssli AG|year=1946|isbn=|location=Zurich|pages=65|language=German}}</ref> Starting in 1944, silk experienced a certain upswing due to the temporary shortage of [[wool]] and [[cotton]]. Following the war, the silk business began to flourish once again. Large supplies of Italian silk were exported to Switzerland, which stimulated the local economy.
== Present ==
=== Decline of the Swiss Silk Industry === [[File:TESTEX heute.jpg|thumb|The Testex AG's headquarters at present]] Following the development of [[Synthetic fiber|synthetic fibers]], particularly after World War II, the Swiss silk industry began processing less and less real silk.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/d/D13965.php|title=Seide|last=AHB|first=Liliane Mottu-Weber /|date=|website=HLS-DHS-DSS.CH|language=German|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>As a result, the demand for traditional silk drying methods declined significantly. In 1970, the company responded to the shifting market conditions by focussing on textile testing and changing its name to Testex AG.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.testex.com/de/leistungen/wer-wir-sind/#box01|title=Le Fil Rouge, Jubiläumsausgabe zum 160-jährigen Bestehen der ehemaligen Seidentrocknungsanstalt Zürich.|last=|first=|date=|website=www.testex.com|language=German|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> This laid the foundation for a new reorganization to a modern testing institute. In 1993, Testex joined the Oeko-Tex Association and began conducting human ecological tests on textiles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.testex.com/en/leistungen/wer-wir-sind/#box01|title=Milestones TESTEX AG.|last=|first=|date=|website=www.testex.com|language=de|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
=== Testex Today === Today, little remains of the silk drying institute. The boom eras of Zurich’s silk industry are a thing of the past, and the Swiss textile industry has long been in decline. The "Seidentrocknungsanstalt", however, has managed to avoid a similar fate. Today, Testex AG is one of the largest textile testing companies in the world, and has experienced significant growth since the turn of the century. At the end of 2006, Testex AG engaged 66 employees,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nzz.ch/articleEPOV6-1.86374|title=Von der «Sidetröckni» zum Hightech-Betrieb - das Textilprüfinstitut Testex: Ist der Teddybär resistent gegen Speichel?|date=2006-12-29|work=Neue Zürcher Zeitung|access-date=2017-08-14|language=de-CH|issn=0376-6829}}</ref> whereas in 2017 the company employs over 200 people in 20 locations worldwide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.testex.com/en/leistungen/wer-wir-sind/|title=TESTEX - Gruppe|last=|first=|date=|website=www.testex.com|language=English|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
== References == <references />

page.title: Times Square Red, Times Square Blue

revision.comment: /* ...Three, Two, One, Contact: Times Square Red */
revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=July 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox book |name=Times Square Red, Times Square Blue |image=Times square red times square blue.jpg |caption=Dust jacket from the first edition |author=[[Samuel R. Delany]] |country=United States |language=English |genre=[[Non-fiction]] |publisher=[[New York University Press]] |release_date=[[1999 in literature|1999]] |media_type=Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]]) |pages=224 (Paperback ed.) |isbn=0-8147-1919-8 |dewey=306.74/09747 21 |congress=HQ146.N7 D45 1999 |oclc=40838591}} '''''Times Square Red, Times Square Blue''''' is a [[non-fiction]] book written by [[science fiction]] author [[Samuel R. Delany]] and published in [[1999 in literature|1999]] by the [[New York University Press]]. The book is a compilation of two separate [[essay]]s: ''Times Square Blue'' and ''...Three, Two, One, Contact: Times Square Red''.
==Contents==
===''Times Square Blue''=== ''Times Square Blue'' is a first-hand narrative of Delany's (often referred to as "Chip," or, occasionally, as "The Professor") sexual exploits in [[Times Square]]'s [[adult movie theater|pornographic movie theaters]] with other men (some [[homosexuality|homosexual]], some [[heterosexuality|heterosexual]]) from 1960 through the mid-1990s. He also describes, in detail, his relationships with these men inside and outside the theatres.
===''...Three, Two, One, Contact: Times Square Red''=== The second essay in the book discusses the nature of [[social relation]]s within the realm of [[urban studies]]. Delany proposes two kinds of relationships, "contact" and "networking," and analyzes the content and benefits of each. He also refers extensively to [[Jane Jacobs]]' ''[[The Death and Life of Great American Cities]]''.
==References== *{{cite web|last=Brown|first=Charles N.|authorlink=Charles N. Brown|author2=William G. Contento|title=The ''Locus'' Index to Science Fiction: 1999 (Books: Listed by Author, Part 1)|website=[[Locus Online|Locus Online (The Locus Index to Science Fiction: Site Directory)]]|url=http://www.locusmag.com/index/yr1999/b12.htm#A373.5|accessdate=January 4, 2008}} *{{cite book|last=Delany|first=Samuel R.|authorlink=Samuel R. Delany|title=Times Square Red, Times Square Blue|origyear=1999|edition=Paperback|year=2001|publisher=[[New York University Press]]|location=New York, New York|isbn=0-8147-1919-8}}
{{Samuel R. Delany}}
